text:
I'm being patient, but my sense is there is plenty of debate to still have. Even the least controversial one, the <https://github.com/JuliaLang/julia/pull/37875|documentation only PR>, has been sitting there for months.

It's absolutely 90% type piracy because most of it extends the functionality of base `range` in different ways that people have proposed. #<https://github.com/JuliaLang/julia/issues/38750|38750> #<https://github.com/JuliaLang/julia/issues/37875|37875> #<https://github.com/JuliaLang/julia/pull/38041|38041> <https://github.com/JuliaLang/julia/pull/39055|#39055>

The 10% not type piracy is because I created a `PartialRange` type as a way of currying parameters.

Anyways, this package is basically a testbed to try all of these proposed extension live along the lines of the former <https://github.com/JuliaArrays/Ranges.jl>

I can understand though if it doesn't belong in the registry. Even if the PRs are merged, I could imagine it might be useful to backport some of the functionality.

It seems apparent there people keep asking for the same functionality over the years. It feels like we've been going in circles since 2018, first deprecating `linrange`... now someone wants `linrange` back (specifically lowercase).

The thought is that maybe if there was a package that just provided the frequently debated syntax that it would curtail the endless circle of PRs.

```Base.range(start::Number, stop, length::Integer) = Base.range(start, stop; length)```
